description: Research-backed scenarios from FBI IC3, FTC, and victim testimonies
source: FBI Internet Crime Report 2023, FTC Fraud Data, Real Victim Testimonies

scenarios.title: Military Romance Scam

conversation.text: Hello beautiful! I saw your profile and felt an instant connection. I'm deployed in Syria but will be home soon.
I know this might sound crazy, but I feel like I've known you my whole life. You're exactly what I've been looking for.
Emergency! My unit is under attack and I need $3000 for emergency communications equipment. My life depends on it!

scenarios.explanation: Military romance scammers create fake profiles using stolen photos and claim deployment to explain inability to meet.
scenarios.victimTestimony: I thought I found my soulmate. He said all the right things and made me feel special. I sent $8,000 before realizing it was fake.

scenarios.title: Pig Butchering Crypto Scam

conversation.text: Hey! Sorry wrong number, but since you're here - do you trade crypto? I just made $50K in 3 days!
Check out my portfolio - I use this exclusive platform my uncle works at. Made 400% returns this month!
Start small - just $500. I'll guide you personally. Limited spots available for new traders.

scenarios.explanation: Pig butchering scams build trust over time before leading victims to fake trading platforms.
scenarios.victimTestimony: They were so convincing with fake screenshots. I invested $25,000 thinking I was getting rich. Lost everything.

scenarios.title: Microsoft Tech Support Scam

conversation.text: CRITICAL ALERT: We detected 47 viruses on your computer. Call 1-800-HELP-NOW immediately!
Your personal data is being accessed by hackers RIGHT NOW. We need remote access to fix this immediately.
Download TeamViewer now and give us code 847392. If you don't act in 10 minutes, all your files will be deleted.

redFlags: Microsoft/Apple never contacts users this way
scenarios.explanation: Tech support scams impersonate legitimate companies to gain computer access and steal money.
scenarios.victimTestimony: I panicked when they said hackers were in my computer. They took control and charged my credit card $800.

scenarios.title: Real Bank Fraud Alert

conversation.text: Fraud Alert: $487.23 transaction at WALMART.COM. If this wasn't you, reply NO or call 1-800-935-9935.
This message is from JPMorgan Chase Bank. For your security, we will never ask for passwords via text.

legitimateFlags: Does not ask for personal information
scenarios.explanation: Banks do send legitimate fraud alerts with official phone numbers and security disclaimers.
scenarios.victimTestimony: I thought this was a scam and ignored it. My card was actually compromised and I lost $2,000.

scenarios.title: Legitimate Package Delivery

conversation.text: Your package from Amazon will be delivered today between 2-6 PM. Track: 1234567890123456
For delivery updates: fedex.com/tracking. FedEx will never ask for payment via text.

scenarios.explanation: Legitimate delivery notifications include real tracking numbers and official websites.
scenarios.victimTestimony: I was so paranoid about package scams that I missed my actual delivery three times.

scenarios.title: Real Remote Job Offer

conversation.text: Hi! We found your resume on LinkedIn. Interested in a remote customer service role? $18/hour + benefits.
Next step would be a 30-minute video interview. I can send you our company info and employee reviews.

scenarios.explanation: Legitimate employers offer interviews, provide company information, and never ask for upfront payments.
scenarios.victimTestimony: I dismissed this as a scam and missed a great job opportunity. They were a real 3-year-old startup.

scenarios.title: Real Account Security Alert

conversation.text: We noticed a login from a new device in Chicago, IL. If this was you, no action needed.
If this wasn't you, secure your account at paypal.com/security. We'll never ask for passwords via email.

scenarios.explanation: Legitimate security alerts provide specific details and official links without requesting credentials.
scenarios.victimTestimony: I ignored this thinking it was phishing, but my account actually was compromised from that location.

scenarios.title: IRS Phone Threat Scam

conversation.text: This is Agent Martinez, Badge #4829, IRS Criminal Investigation Division. Our records show you owe $3,247 in back taxes with penalties.
You have 2 hours to resolve this before we issue an arrest warrant. This is your final notice.
To stop the arrest warrant, you must pay immediately via iTunes gift cards. This is the ONLY way to resolve this matter.

scenarios.explanation: Government impersonation scams use fear, false authority, and urgency to panic victims into paying quickly without thinking.
scenarios.victimTestimony: I was terrified they would arrest me. I bought $2,000 in gift cards before my daughter told me it was fake.

scenarios.title: Grandparent Emergency Scam

conversation.text: Grandma, it's me! I'm in jail and need $5,000 for bail. I'm so scared and embarrassed.
Please don't tell Mom and Dad. I was stupid and got arrested for DUI. I need you to send money now.
The lawyer says you need to wire the money in the next hour or I'll be in jail all weekend. Please help me!

redFlags: Unexpected call claiming to be family member
Asks you not to tell other family
Requests wire transfer or gift cards
scenarios.explanation: Grandparent scams target elderly people by impersonating grandchildren in emergency situations.
scenarios.victimTestimony: It sounded just like my grandson. I was so worried I sent the money right away. Later found out he was safe at home.

scenarios.title: Real Medical Insurance Notification

conversation.text: Your insurance claim #BC789456 for $245.67 has been processed. View details at bcbs.com/claims
Questions? Call the member services number on your insurance card. We never request personal info via email.

scenarios.explanation: Legitimate insurance notifications provide specific details and direct you to official channels for questions.
scenarios.victimTestimony: I almost deleted this thinking it was spam, but it was my actual medical claim being processed.

scenarios.title: Fake Work-from-Home Job Scam

conversation.text: Congratulations! You've been selected for our $45/hour data entry position. No experience required!
To secure your position, please send $195 for your starter kit and training materials. You'll earn this back in your first week!
Act fast! We only have 3 positions left and over 500 applicants. Send payment within 24 hours to guarantee your spot.

redFlags: Requires upfront payment for job materials
Unrealistic high hourly wage for simple work
Generic email domain (.biz instead of company domain)
Promises to earn back initial payment quickly
scenarios.explanation: Legitimate employers never require upfront payments for job positions, training materials, or starter kits.
scenarios.victimTestimony: I needed work desperately and sent $195 for the 'starter kit.' Never heard from them again and the website disappeared.
